It's not just about internet connection; it's specifically about the ability to connect to Riot's servers. There are times when I've had massively shitty ping on LoL just minutes after superb connections on CoD or DCUO.

Um, no, unless you have insanely bad internet, the difference is single digit milliseconds.  Seriously.  The reason is really very simple:
For bandwidth usage to have a measurable impact on latency, you have to be using close to your full bandwidth at some point between the two systems.  Unless you have better than a gigabit link to your ISP or there's a satellite link somewhere between you and Riot, the link from you to your ISP is the slowest link between you and the servers.  So, if you're not close to fully saturating your link to your ISP, you should see near zero difference between in game and out of game ping.  If you do see more than a few milliseconds of difference, then something is wrong _somewhere_ between you and Riot.

If you have a shitty ping in the launcher, then it's because of your own internet connection. And that's pretty easy to detect, just go to Speedtest.net or any other site that check your connection.

Once the game starts, you're connected to a server that spins up the game for you. You don't know beforehand which server on Riot's network will host your game, and I'm 99.9999% sure Riot does neither. It's determined by an optimization algorithm that factors in a multitude of parameters.

So having a ping in the Launcher will do absolutely nothing for you.

How do you think games work? You input commands into the game, what you did gets sent to a packet to a server and the server sends you back what other players did. If you are experiencing shitty internet problems, then obviously this is all going to take longer since it will take longer for your internet to download the packet and upload the packet.

Pinging in CMD does the same thing, it sends 4 packets, and then gets the packet back if the connection is good.

Hell a lot of LoL exploits were made by letting scripts send packets that players would not normally be able to send (Sion instantly changing directions during ult, Ashe being able to cast her old Q on teamates which let them have abilities as AAs (Azir passive, TF red card, old Fiora ult, etc). Riot patched it up since then though.

Oh boi... where do I even begin...
If you think there is 1 giant server that hosts all the currently played games in LoL, and every single player who is playing is sending and receiving packets from the same IP address, then this is where you're already fundamentally wrong.

Every game is hosted on a Server. This server runs a magnitude of services. Those services communicate with each player connected to that game. They listen for the player input and send back the result and what other players do.
As long as you are in the lobby, this server is not yet identified, as to where the game will take place. Then as soon as the loading screen starts, a new Game ID is created. This game ID uniquely identifies the current game you are in. This is how yo u can look up certain games online, or determine if a player is currently in a game (e.g. on LolSumo) - using that game ID. 
You pinging while in champion select means you are testing your connection to the server where champion select takes place. However, no game has started yet. And also no Game ID has been created yet. Hence, as long as you are in champ select, you cannot use the RiotAPI or an app like LoLSumo to check your opponents, because the game hasn't been created yet.

This has absolutely nothing to do with whether exploits work or not.
If you're using exploits, all you need to do is use Wireshark or Cain&Abel, follow where you send your game packets to or where you get them from, and you can find out the IP of the server you're connected to.
Then if you're witty and malicious, you modify the packets you are sending or you send fake packets to that server which every single player in your game is connected to, and let the server process your input.
while you are correct that pinging the launcher doesn't represent your connection to the in-game client, you CAN ping the server directly to get an idea of your in-game latency.  See my other post.

You can ping a server, yes. But you don't know which one you'll be playing on.
Plus, I believe they are using Amazon AWS (or Azure, but I think it's Amazon AWS) and hence it's impossible to know on which physical location the game will be hosted.

Agreed, but you missed one of the points that most people don't get:
Just like scaling on abilities, network latency is an integral bit of information to the game.  We absolutely should not need to use third party software to determine it (especially since we can't actually ping the servers directly outside of the client).
Yes, but it isn't Riot's responsibility to cover your inability to notice you're torrenting porn when you queue for a game.

There are all kinds of other reasons that your latency could be crap.  Windows updates immediately come to mind, as do hardware problems, other people on the network, and quite a few other things that aren't really under your control.  Put another way, how am I supposed to know if my roommate has decided to reinstall Destiny or my ISP is suddenly having latency issues?

I could care less about things that I have control over.  I literally built my own router from scratch just to cut my network latency, so I'd say I've got significantly better control over my network conditions than a vast majority of people.  There are still things I have zero control over though, and I shouldn't need to be using third party software to just see if any such things are likely to be an immediate issue the moment I start a game.
